newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK unemployment shrinks, rate seen falling further.
newsitem.headline: HK unemployment shrinks, rate seen falling further.

text.p: Unemployment in Hong Kong, which hit a 10 year peak last year, shrank in the third quarter of 1996 and economists said they expect to see it ease further.
Hong Kong's Census and Statistics Department said the unemployment rate for July to September slipped to 2.6 percent from 2.8 percent in the June-to-August period.
Unemployment in Hong Kong -- where a labour shortage had until recently permitted workers to job hop at will -- hit a 10-year high of 3.6 percent in the August-October 1995 period.
Economists said they expect the trend to persist and estimated unemployment would hover around 2.3 to 2.5 percent by year end.
This would compare with 3.5 percent in the last quarter of 1995.
"I think the improvement was better than expected," said K.K. Chan, chief economist, at Nomura Research Institute.
"It will continue to fall, because Hong Kong's economy is bottoming out," he said.
Connie Leung, head of the Asian Research Group at HSBC Asset Management, said signs of an economic pick-up suggested the jobless rate would continue to ease.
"The economy has improved. The property market and consumption power have started to pick up a little," she said.
